section.title: Proprietà del progetto
section.para: This dialog is accessible by selecting in the menu.
The dialog that is displayed when you create a new project, after you have named it, is the same as the one described here. Vedere per dettagli.

warning.para: The options displayed in or are always the global settings and never the project specific settings.
If you have defined project specific settings here, they will supercede any modifications you make to the global settings and the latter will not be taken into account in your project.

section.title: Lingue
section.para: You can either enter the source and target languages by hand, or use the drop-down menus.
Language codes are used for the , the , the , the , etc.

OmegaT automatically selects the tokenizers corresponding to the source and target languages but you can manually modify the settings. Tokenizers are useful to provide better matches since they each correspond to a specific language.

listitem.para: Sentence-level segmentation splits the source file “paragraphs” into segments based on segmentation rules.
Uncheck the box if you prefer not to segment the paragraphs.
By default, segmentation rules are global and apply to all projects.
You can access the global rules with in the menu.
If you want this project to use project specific segmentation rules (local rules) and not global rules, click , on the right, or start OmegaT from the command line. See for details.
If you use local rules, you can still access the global rules, but modifying them will have no effect on your project.

note.para: Changing the segmentation rules settings during a translation does not modify the segments registered in the project translation memory.

Switching from sentence to paragraph segmentation mid-translation may force OmegaT to upgrade old translation memories that did not use sentence segmentation, but not vice versa. However, OmegaT will attempt to create fuzzy matches for paragraphs by combining existing sentence translations.

If you change the segmentation while translating, you will have to reload the project for the new segmentation to take effect. This will split or merge some previously translated segments, which will therefore no longer be considered translated. Nonetheless, their original translation will still be in the project memory.

listitem.para: See for general explanations about segmentation (global or local, paragraph or sentence, setting, etc.)
By default, segmentation rules are global and apply to all projects.
Segmentation rules found when you open Preferences – (with in the menu) are global rules.
Use this button to create local rules specific to your project. Check the Make the segmentation rules project specific box, and adjust the segmentation rules as desired.
The new set of rules will be stored in the file of the folder of the project and will supersede the global segmentation rules.

note.para: To disable local segmentation rules, uncheck the box or remove that file.

warning.para: If you use local rules, you can still access the global rules, but modifying them will have no effect on your project.

If there are non-unique segments in the source documents, checking this option will set the first translated segment as the default translation and automatically use the same target text in the remaining repeated segments.
You can use to assign an alternative translation to segments that require a different translation.
If not checked, all segments can be assigned a different translation.

If checked, no formatting (inline) tags will be displayed in the source segments. This is especially useful when dealing with texts where inline formatting is not particularly useful (e.g., OCRed PDF, or poorly converted .odt or .docx files.)

note.para: The tags are not really removed from the document, but rather stacked at the end of the segment. In most cases, this should not keep the translated file from opening. If you just need to reduce the number of tags, you can use the script. Vedere per i dettagli.

listitem.para: This area displays the external post-processing command (a script to rename files, for instance) that will be applied each time is used.
By default, post-processing commands are global and are available to all projects. They are defined in Preferences – .

note.para: For security purposes, project-based external commands are disabled by default. You can enable them by checking Preferences – in the preferences.

listitem.para: By default, file filter settings are global and are shared by all projects. They are found in Preferences – .
Use this button to create local file filters specific to your project. Check the Make the file filter settings project specific box, and adjust the settings as desired.
The new set of filters will be stored in the file of the folder of the project and will supersede the general set of file filters.

note.para: To disable project specific file filters, uncheck the box or remove that file.

section.title: Posizioni dei file
section.para: An OmegaT translation project consists of a number of resources in separate folders.

When a new project is created, OmegaT proposes to create a project folder that contains all the resources used in the translation, but that structure is not compulsory. Resource folders can be located anywhere on your machine, including on shared disks. Vedere per dettagli.
You can modify the structure of your project by adding or removing files from the folders, or even by changing the folders the project will use, at will, even during the course of the translation.
You can access all the locations with and its submenus.

listitem.para: The Browse button is available for all the user-defined project resources.

note.para: Resources do not have to be contained in the default project folder that OmegaT creates. You can select any folder that you want to hold your resources, even folders located on shared disks.

listitem.para: Click on the button to select the folder that you want to use instead of the default resource folder.

OmegaT will consider that this folder contains the files that you want to translate. It will try to read all the files at once, and will display in the editor the translatable contents that it has found. Vedere per dettagli.

If the folder is empty, if none of the files contain translatable contents, or if there are no files supported by OmegaT’s file filters, OmegaT will tell you that the folder is empty. Vedere Preferenze – per i dettagli.
Click Exclusions... to define the files or folders that will be ignored by OmegaT. Un file o una cartella ignorata:
is not displayed in the pane,
is not taken into account in the window, and
is not copied to the folder when the translated files are created.
The Exclusion patterns dialog, allows you to add or remove a pattern, or to edit one by double-clicking it, or selecting it and pressing F2. You can use wildcards that follow the Apache ant syntax.

OmegaT will consider that this folder contains the files that you want to use as reference translation memories. It will try to read all the files at once, and will match their contents to the segment you are translating. Vedere per dettagli.
If matches are found, they will be displayed in the .

OmegaT will consider that this folder contains the files that you want to use as reference glossaries. It will try to read all the files at once, and will match their contents to the segment you are translating. Vedere per dettagli.
If matches are found, they will be displayed in the pane.
The writeable glossary if the file that OmegaT will use when you want to add translated glossary terms to your project. Use to add a term.
Added items are automatically recognized and displayed if they match terms in the current segment. Vedere Preferenze – per i dettagli.

OmegaT will consider that this folder contains the files that you want to use as reference dictionaries. It will try to read all the files at once, and will match their contents to the segment you are translating. Vedere per dettagli.
If matches are found, they will be displayed in the pane.

This folder is the place where OmegaT will copy the contents of the folder where all the translated segments will be replaced by their translation and the non-translated segments will be kept in the original language.
The folder structure will reflect the copied contents and files that are not supported by OmegaT’s file filters will be copied without modifications.
Use or to create the translated files. See for details.
This folder is the place where OmegaT will copy the current state of the translation in the form of TMX files.
The TMX files will contain only the segments that have been translated at the moment the translated files have been created with or .
This checkbox lists lets you choose in which format you want OmegaT to create the above TMX files. Vedere per dettagli.
An “OmegaT” TMX contains the tags that OmegaT created, in a form that can only be properly used by an OmegaT project.
A “level 1” TMX contains only textual data and has removed all tag information.
A “level 2” TMX contains textual data along with tags encapsulated in a way that is compatible with other CAT tools.
See TMX 1.4b Specification for details.
